description:
Anopheles ziemanni is a species of mosquito that belongs to the genus Anopheles, which includes several malaria-transmitting mosquito species. It is primarily found in parts of Africa, particularly in the central and eastern regions of the continent.

Anopheles ziemanni is a medium-sized mosquito with a characteristic body shape and wing pattern typical of the Anopheles genus. It has a slender body, long legs, and a long, narrow proboscis used for blood-feeding. The wings are typically mottled or speckled in appearance, which is a distinguishing feature of this species.

The primary habitat of Anopheles ziemanni includes various freshwater breeding sites, such as swamps, marshes, and slow-moving streams or rivers. The females of this species are known to feed on a variety of vertebrate hosts, including humans, and can potentially transmit the parasites that cause malaria.

Anopheles ziemanni is considered an important vector of malaria in certain regions of Africa, particularly in areas where it is the dominant Anopheles species. Its role in the transmission of malaria parasites and its distribution patterns have been the subject of various epidemiological and entomological studies to better understand its public health significance.
